summary: By now, every state has passed legislation modeled after New York’s Married Women’s Property Act (1848), granting married women some control over their property and earnings.

Muller v State of Oregon, 208 U.S. 412 (1908): The U.S. Supreme Court upholds Oregon’s 10-hour workday for women. The win is a two-edged sword: the protective legislation implies that women are physic

Margaret Sanger tests the validity of New York’s anti-contraception law by establishing a clinic in Brooklyn. The most well-known of birth control advocates, she is one of hundreds arrested over a 40-
Jeanette Rankin of Montana is elected the first woman member of the U.S. House of representatives.

New York v. Sanger, 222 NY 192, 118 N.E. 637 (Court of Appeals 1917), National Archives, Records of the U.S. Supreme Court, RG 267 (MSDME-CDS C 15:298). Margaret Sanger wins her suit in New York to al
The Nineteenth Amendment to the U.S. Constitution is ratified. It declares: “The right of citizens of the United States to vote shall not be denied or abridged by the United States or by any State on
Florence Ellinwood Allen of Ohio becomes the first woman elected to a state supreme court.
National Woman’s Party proposes Constitutional amendment: “Men and women shall have equal rights throughout the United States and in every place subject to its jurisdiction. Congress shall have power
Radice v. New York, a New York state case, upholds a law that forbade waitresses from working the night shift but made an exception for entertainers and ladies’ room attendants.
Genevieve Rose Cline of Ohio becomes the first woman to be a federal judge.
United States v. One Package of Japanese Pessaries, 13 F. Supp.334 (E.D.N.Y 1936) aff’d 86 F 2d 737 (2nd Cir. 1936), won judicial approval of medicinal use of birth control.
The U.S. Supreme Court upholds Washington state’s minimum wage laws for women.
The United Nations establishes the Commission on the Status of Women to safeguard women’s rights and oversee their global status.
Fay v. New York, 332 U.S. 261 (1947), the U.S. Supreme Court says women are equally qualified with men to serve on juries but are granted an exemption and may serve or not as women choose.
Women’s Paycheck Act (California)
Emma Baker is the first woman to receive a Ph.D. from a Canadian university.
On January 29, women in Manitoba become the first in Canada to vote in a provincial election.
Some women were granted the right to vote in federal elections.
Agnes Macphail is the first woman elected to the House of Commons
Canada’s court defines women as “persons” in the Persons Case.
Decriminalization of same-sex intimacy for consenting adults.
Report on the Royal Commission on the Status of Women tabled in Parliament.
Position of Minister for Status of Women created.
Office of the Coordinator, Status of Women, becomes federal agency.
Roberta Jamieson becomes the first Indigenous woman in Canada to earn a law degree.
Canadian Human Rights Act passed, ensuring equal pay and forbidding sex discrimination.
Immigration Act amended to remove homosexuality as inadmissibility.
Persons Day is celebrated, marking 50th anniversary of the Persons Case.
Canada ratifies UN CEDAW convention.
Canadian Charter of Rights and Freedoms includes 'sex' as protected ground.
Bill C-127 makes sexual assault in marriage a crime.
Bill C-31 reinstates Indian status for women who lost it via marriage.
National Day of Remembrance and Action on Violence Against Women established.
October designated as Women’s History Month in Canada.
Canadian Forces ends service restrictions on LGBTQ.
Kim Campbell becomes first (and only) female Prime Minister of Canada.
Federal Plan for Gender Equality and Employment Equity Act come into force.
Canada adopts Beijing Declaration on gender equality and rights.
Supreme Court extends equality rights to sexual orientation.
Human Rights Act amended to protect sexual orientation.
Benefits and Obligations Act includes same-sex couples.
Human Rights Commission recommends proactive pay equity system.
Standing Committee on Status of Women established in Parliament.
Same-sex marriage becomes legal across Canada.
Nadine Caron becomes first Indigenous General Surgeon in Canada.
First Trans March held in Toronto Pride.
Gender Equity in Indian Registration Act (Bill C-3) receives royal assent.
UN adopts International Day of the Girl under Canada's leadership.
First full Minister of Status of Women appointed federally.
Cabinet becomes gender-balanced for the first time.
National Inquiry into Missing and Murdered Indigenous Women and Girls launched.
2SLGBTQI+ Secretariat created.
Gender identity & expression protected in Human Rights Act (Bill C-16).
Canada launches first federal GBV Strategy: “Itʼs Time”.
Formal apology for purge of LGBTQ2 persons from RCMP, military, civil service.
Interim report released by Inquiry on Missing and Murdered Indigenous Women.
LGBT Purge Class Action Settlement Agreement approved.
Historical unjust convictions expunged.
Canada launches Feminist International Assistance Policy.
Gender Equality Week launched in September.
Gender Budgeting Act passed.
WAGE Canada legislated as full department.
Pay Equity Act passed for public service fairness.
Bill S-3 ends remaining Indian Act sex-based inequities.
Outdated sexual offences repealed.
LGBTQ2-targeted funding programs launched.
Final report on Missing and Murdered Indigenous Women released.
Karen Jensen named first Pay Equity Commissioner.
National Strategy to Combat Human Trafficking launched.
Gender parity reached in Senate.
Canada includes transgender and non-binary data in Census.
Mary Simon appointed first Indigenous Governor General.
RoseAnne Archibald becomes first female AFN National Chief.
Cassidy Caron elected first female Métis National Council President.
Joint Declaration for Canada Free of Gender-Based Violence signed.
50-30 Corporate Diversity Challenge launched.
Conversion therapy officially banned.
Bill C-25 mandates corporate diversity disclosure.
Canada launches Federal 2SLGBTQI+ Action Plan.
Blood donation screening no longer excludes based on gender/sexuality.
Mexican women gained the right to divorce, and gradually, rights to alimony and child custody were recognized.
The First Feminist Congress was held in Yucatán, advocating for educational equality and equal pay in the Constitution.
During the Mexican Revolution, female 'Soldaderas' fought in battle and served in logistics and healthcare, becoming national symbols.
Yucatán became the first state to grant women the right to vote. Elvia Carrillo Puerto and two others were elected to the state legislature but later forced to resign.
On October 17, the Mexican Constitution was amended to grant women the right to vote and run for office at the national level.
On July 3, women voted in federal elections for the first time, electing the 43rd Chamber of Deputies.
María Lavalle Urbina became the first female president of the Mexican Senate and represented Mexico on the UN Commission on the Status of Women.
Griselda Álvarez became the governor of Colima, the first female governor in Mexican history.
Mexico's Supreme Court ruled that criminalizing abortion is unconstitutional, paving the way for nationwide legalization.
The Qing government issued the Foot-binding Prohibition Edict, beginning official efforts to end the practice of foot-binding.
The Qing government introduced regulations for girls' schools, formally including women's education in the national system. Girls' schools like Shanghai Wuben Female School were founded.
After the May Fourth Movement, the New Culture Movement advocated democracy and science, calling for women's freedom in marriage and education.
Peking University admitted female students for the first time, allowing women into higher education.
The Nationalist Government promulgated the Civil Code, granting women property inheritance rights.
The Marriage Law abolished arranged marriages and recognized women's right to divorce and property.
The All-China Federation of Trade Unions encouraged women's employment and equal pay.
The Constitution of the People's Republic of China guaranteed women's equal rights with men in all spheres.
China launched a national literacy campaign, establishing rural women's literacy classes.
China attended the first UN World Conference on Women, linking women's liberation with proletarian revolution.
Women's admission rate in colleges rose to 30% after the resumption of college entrance exams.
The revised Women's Federation Charter clarified the federation's political role in women's rights.
The Law on the Protection of Women's Rights and Interests was enacted.
China hosted the Fourth UN World Conference on Women in Beijing, setting gender equality as national policy.
Wu Yi was appointed Vice Premier, the first woman to hold the post in China's State Council.
Liu Yang was selected as China's first female astronaut.
Revised regulations extended maternity leave and banned gender discrimination at work.
Tu Youyou won the Nobel Prize for discovering artemisinin, becoming the first Chinese woman laureate in science.
Two-child policy began; maternity leave extended; paternity leave piloted.
During COVID-19, over 70% of medical staff sent to Hubei were women. Experts like Li Lanjuan and Chen Wei played key roles.
Zhang Guimei received the July 1 Medal for helping 2,000+ girls in poor areas go to college.
China's 2021–2030 Women's Development Outline included gender equality in compulsory education.
‘She Economy’ surpassed 4.5 trillion yuan; over 30% of entrepreneurs were women.
Yun Hui-sun organized and led Korea’s first female righteous army against Japanese colonial rule. She also wrote the 'Song of the Righteous Women Soldiers'.
Yu Gwan-sun became a symbol of the March 1st Movement for Korean independence. She led protests and died in prison at the age of 17.
Korea's Family Law was enacted, though discriminatory. Women's groups started campaigns for reform, leading to major changes by 1991.
Mass protests broke out in South Korea against spycam crimes and sexual violence, pushing the government to strengthen laws and enforcement.
The Constitutional Court of Korea ruled the abortion ban unconstitutional, paving the way for its legalization.
Yoshioka Yayoi founded Tokyo Women's Medical University, Japan's first medical school for women.
Hiratsuka Raichō launched 'Seitō', the first women's literary magazine in Japan, advocating for independence.
The New Women's Association was founded by Hiratsuka and Ichikawa to advance women's political and civil rights.
Japanese women gained the right to vote under reforms during Allied occupation.
Masa Nakayama was appointed as the Minister of Health and Welfare, becoming Japan's first female cabinet member.
The Equal Employment Opportunity Law was enacted to reduce gender discrimination in the workplace.
Takako Doi became Speaker of the House of Representatives, the first woman to hold the position.
#KuToo movement started, protesting mandatory high heels for women in workplaces, gaining national attention.
Singapore enacted the Women's Charter, establishing gender equality in marriage and protecting women's rights in divorce and property.
Women were allowed to join the police force for the first time, marking entry into law enforcement.
The first female Member of Parliament, Mary Chee Bee Kiang, was elected, marking women's entry into political leadership.
The male-preference clause in the royal succession law was abolished, allowing women to inherit the throne symbolically.
Halimah Yacob became Singapore's first female President, breaking new ground for women in head-of-state roles.
The government released the White Paper on Women's Development, proposing measures to advance gender equality.
Singapore extended paternity leave from 2 to 4 weeks (2 weeks optional), promoting shared family responsibilities.
First organized women's delegation submitted a demand for suffrage to the Viceroy of India in New Delhi.
Child Marriage Restraint Act passed, setting the minimum marriage age for women at 14.
India gained independence; women like Hansa Mehta were members of the Constitution Drafting Committee.
The Indian Constitution came into effect, granting women universal suffrage and legal equality.
The Hindu Marriage Act passed, granting women legal rights in marriage.
Indira Gandhi became the first female Prime Minister of India.
The National Commission for Women was established to address women’s issues.
73rd and 74th Constitutional Amendments guaranteed at least 33% female representation in local government.
The Vishaka ruling provided legal guidelines against workplace sexual harassment.
The Criminal Law (Amendment) Act was passed to strengthen penalties for sexual violence.
The Supreme Court ruled women must be allowed to enter the Sabarimala Temple.
Women were allowed to join the National Defence Academy for the first time.
Finland became the first country in the world to grant women full suffrage and the right to stand for election.
Around 500,000 people joined the 'Women's Sunday' suffrage demonstration in London.
40,000 women marched in the Coronation Procession to demand suffrage in George V's coronation year.
Thousands of women walked from across the UK to London in the 'Great Pilgrimage' for suffrage.
Women marched in London on March 8 to support suffrage.
UK passed the Representation of the People Act, giving voting rights to women over 30 with property.
UK passed equal voting rights for women and men (from age 21).
French women gained the right to vote by government decree.
Switzerland passed a national referendum granting women federal suffrage.
90% of Icelandic women went on strike against gender inequality, prompting legal reforms.
Liechtenstein granted women suffrage through a national referendum.
Mass protest in Poland against proposed abortion ban, leading to its withdrawal.
Polish court ruling restricted abortion, sparking nationwide protests called the 'Women's Strike'.
Women in Norway actively participated in post-war general elections, confirming their political rights.
Italian women voted in the national referendum to decide between monarchy and republic.
Germany's Basic Law established legal gender equality.
Greek women gained the right to vote and run in parliamentary elections.
France passed the Equal Pay Act, mandating equal pay for equal work.
The UK introduced the Equal Pay Act proposal to eliminate gender pay gap (passed in 1970).
Sweden introduced national parental leave, supporting shared parenting.
German women held a 'trouser protest' in Frankfurt against workplace discrimination.
Austria repealed the law naming the husband as the head of the family.
Portugal saw its first female presidential candidate, Maria de Lourdes.
The Netherlands introduced mandatory gender-neutral education policies.
Sweden launched a national gender mainstreaming strategy in legislation.
Scottish Women's Alliance founded in Glasgow to boost women's participation in elections.
France enacted the Political Parity Law requiring gender balance on candidate lists.
Finland's Anneli Jäätteenmäki became the first female PM and commander-in-chief.
Angela Merkel became the first female Chancellor of Germany.
Spain enacted the Gender Equality Law mandating balanced gender representation in leadership.
Large feminist protests occurred in Russia symbolized by the Pussy Riot case.
BBC pledged to ensure gender balance among leadership and media guests.
300,000 women in Switzerland joined a national women's strike for equal pay and safety.
France extended the legal abortion window from 12 to 14 weeks.
Denmark established the Equal Opportunities Council to promote gender equality in education and work.
Norway passed a quota law requiring 40% women on party candidate lists.
Spain passed a law legalizing abortion under specific conditions.
Iceland's Vigdís Finnbogadóttir was re-elected for a third term, becoming the longest-serving female president.
First woman elected to Hungary's parliament, starting post-communist political participation.
Bulgarian women helped pass labor and anti-domestic violence laws in post-socialist reforms.
Slovenia's Constitutional Court ruled that abortion rights cannot be revoked.
Italy passed the Domestic Workers Protection Act, securing labor rights for women at home.
Mari-Ann Kelam became the first Estonian woman elected to the European Parliament.
Croatian women's groups pushed to criminalize domestic violence.
Lithuania opened the Women's Law Aid Center to offer free legal services to abuse victims.
Ukraine saw the first 'Women Are Not Decorations' protest against objectification of female politicians.
France appointed Najat Vallaud-Belkacem as first female Education Minister, who reformed gender education.
Ana Brnabić became Serbia’s first openly gay cabinet minister.
Romania passed new laws combating domestic violence, including emergency restraining orders.
Ireland implemented the Reproductive Health Act, providing legal abortion services.
Sanna Marin became the world's youngest PM and led a female-majority cabinet in Finland.
Germany's court supported gender-neutral bathrooms, addressing needs of women and non-binary people.
Spain passed the Menstrual Equality Law, offering paid menstrual leave — the first in Europe.
After the Russian Revolution in Petrograd, the Bolshevik regime granted women suffrage and the right to be elected.
The Zhenotdel (Women's Department) was established in Moscow to promote literacy, employment, and family reform for women. Free abortion was legalized in 1920.
Valentina Tereshkova became the first woman to travel into space, launched from Moscow.
Russia established the National Coalition Against Domestic Violence to advocate for anti-violence legislation.
Women's rights groups held demonstrations in Saint Petersburg to protest the decriminalization of domestic violence.
Yaa Asantewaa led the Ashanti Empire's resistance against British colonialism, becoming the first female war leader.
African women organized the first protest against pass laws in Bloemfontein, South Africa.
Igbo women launched the 'Women's War' in Aba to protest colonial taxation.
Mrs. Oyinkan Abayomi founded the Nigerian Women's Party in Lagos to promote education and political participation.
About 20,000 women marched to Pretoria's Union Buildings against apartheid pass laws; August 9 is now National Women's Day.
Women actively joined the FRELIMO liberation struggle in Mozambique, advocating for independence and gender equality.
Algerian women fought in the war of independence and later sought legal equality.
Angolan women played a key role in the independence struggle and post-independence reforms.
Market women in Conakry protested government price controls in the 'Market Women's Uprising'.
Zimbabwean women gained voting rights and contributed to nation-building post-independence.
UN Third World Conference on Women held in Nairobi, advancing global women's rights.
ANC Women's League was established in South Africa to push for gender equality laws.
Rwandan women led post-genocide reconstruction and achieved world-leading parliamentary representation.
African Women's Conference held in Cotonou, Benin, drafting the African Women's Rights Declaration.
South Africa passed the Equality and Prevention of Unfair Discrimination Act.
African Union adopted the Maputo Protocol in Mozambique to protect women's rights.
Ellen Johnson Sirleaf elected President of Liberia, Africa's first female elected head of state.
South Africa unveiled a monument in Pretoria honoring the 1956 Women's March.
Egypt’s Supreme Court ruled women could serve as judges.
Joyce Banda became Vice President of Malawi, later ascending to the presidency.
Tunisia’s draft constitution guaranteed women’s rights and gender equality.
Niger launched the Girls’ Education Initiative to boost literacy and schooling for girls.
South Africa passed the Gender Equality Bill to enhance legal protections for women.
Women's parliamentary representation in Ghana increased, advancing gender equality policy.
Morocco passed laws prohibiting sexual harassment and violence against women.
Ethiopia’s Prime Minister appointed a gender-balanced cabinet.
Sudanese women played a central role in protests that led to regime change.
Women's groups in Mali protested gender-based violence, pushing for legal protections.
Samia Suluhu Hassan became Tanzania’s first female president.
Sierra Leone passed the Gender Equality and Women's Empowerment Act mandating 30% representation for women.
The first Pan-African Women in Tech Conference was held in Cape Town, promoting African women's participation in AI and technology.
Uganda launched the National Women Entrepreneurship Fund to support female-led SMEs and startups.
The number of female MPs in Algeria rose significantly as parliament began drafting gender parity reform legislation.
Côte d'Ivoire passed the Anti-Gender Violence Law to enhance punishment for domestic and sexual violence.
Nigeria launched the 'Back to School for Girls' initiative, helping tens of thousands of out-of-school girls return to education.
Namibia approved the Gender Equality Strategy and Action Plan (2018–2022).
Madagascar passed the Anti-Human Trafficking Law with a focus on protecting women and children.
Botswana launched women's land rights reforms, officially recognizing women as landowners.
Niger's Maradi region began the 'Zero Tolerance for Female Genital Mutilation' campaign and enforced punitive legislation.
Mauritania established the first national women's protection hotline and shelter network.
María Abella supported the creation of a women's center in Montevideo to promote women's rights discussions.
Paulina Luisi became Uruguay's first woman to earn a medical degree and joined international women's conferences.
The first International Women's Congress was held in Buenos Aires, Argentina, promoting women's political participation.
María Jesús Alvarado Rivera founded the 'Feminine Evolution' group in Lima to promote women's education and political involvement.
Magda Portal was exiled for political activism and later helped found the APRA party, advocating for women's political roles.
Matilde Hidalgo became the first woman in Latin America to vote in a national election in Machala, Ecuador.
Ecuador's constitution granted women full suffrage, making it the first South American country to do so.
Fanny Edelman helped establish the Argentine Women's Union to support women's roles in politics.
Uruguayan women voted for the first time in a national election, years after suffrage was constitutionally granted.
Argentina passed Law 13,010, granting women the right to vote and be elected.
Argentina reaffirmed women's suffrage in law with Eva Perón playing a key role.
Argentine women voted in national elections for the first time, electing female MPs.
Peru granted women voting rights, marking a milestone in the women's movement.
Paraguay granted women full suffrage, the last South American country to do so.
Peru established the National Women's Commission to promote women's education and work.
Colombia passed the Family Law to protect women's rights in the household.
Argentina limited paternal authority and legalized divorce, improving women's legal standing.
Brazil's new constitution guaranteed gender equality and prohibited discrimination.
Argentina implemented a gender quota law, mandating at least 30% female candidates on party lists.
Bolivia criminalized domestic violence with its Family Violence Law.
Peru honored María Elena Moyano for her advocacy for women's rights.
Venezuela’s constitution banned gender discrimination and violence.
Michelle Bachelet was elected as Chile’s first female president.
Cristina Fernández de Kirchner became Argentina’s first elected female president.
Dilma Rousseff was elected Brazil’s first female head of state.
Colombia passed laws to prohibit gender-based discrimination and violence.
'Ni Una Menos' protests erupted in Argentina against femicide and gender violence.
Uruguay enacted the Gender Equality Law to promote women’s equality in politics and work.
Massive protests broke out in Chile demanding reforms in education and anti-discrimination laws.
Colombian women led national protests demanding action against gender violence.
Argentina legalized abortion up to 14 weeks of pregnancy.
Colombia's Constitutional Court legalized abortion up to 24 weeks.
Peru launched a national gender equality policy to reduce gender disparities.
Brazil required at least 30% female representation on corporate boards.
Chile’s constitutional draft included gender equality provisions to ensure political representation.
Uruguay launched a Women’s Empowerment Plan to support women entrepreneurs.
Venezuelan parliament reached a record 50% female representation.
Argentina implemented an educational policy promoting gender equality and women’s history education.
Colombia outlawed marriage under 18 to protect girls’ rights.
The murder of model María José Estupiñán in Cúcuta sparked national outrage over femicide.
Author Selva Almada faced political backlash for supporting Ni Una Menos, showing ongoing feminist struggles.
Brazilian women’s rights groups campaigned for legislation requiring 30% female board members.
Chile’s constitutional reforms ensured gender representation in politics.
Uruguay relaunched its Women's Empowerment Plan supporting female entrepreneurship.
New Zealand women gained the right to run for Parliament, expanding their political participation.
Elizabeth McCombs was elected as New Zealand's first female Member of Parliament.
Iriaka Rātana became the first Māori woman elected to Parliament.
Jenny Shipley became New Zealand’s first female Prime Minister.
Helen Clark became the second female Prime Minister and later head of UNDP.
Jacinda Ardern became the third female Prime Minister and one of the youngest female heads of state.
Nanaia Mahuta became New Zealand’s first Māori female Foreign Minister.
The Commonwealth Franchise Act granted non-Indigenous women the right to vote and stand for federal election, making Australia the first country to do so.
Women voted and stood for federal election for the first time; four women ran as candidates.
Edith Cowan became the first woman elected to an Australian parliament (WA Legislative Assembly).
The Country Women's Association (CWA) was founded to improve rural women's lives.
Dorothy Tangney and Enid Lyons were elected to the Senate and House of Representatives, becoming the first women in the federal parliament.
Annabelle Rankin was appointed Minister for Housing, becoming Australia's first female federal minister.
The Arbitration Commission ruled that women should receive equal minimum wages to men.
Margaret Guilfoyle became the first woman to hold a cabinet-level ministerial role, in education.
The Sex Discrimination Act came into effect, banning discrimination and harassment based on gender.
Rosemary Follett became Chief Minister of ACT, the first female state or territory leader.
Quentin Bryce became Queensland’s first female Governor and later Australia’s first female Governor-General.
Elizabeth Evatt became the first Australian elected to the UN Human Rights Committee, advancing women’s rights.
Quentin Bryce became the first woman appointed as Governor-General of Australia.
Julia Gillard became Australia’s first female Prime Minister.
Queensland legalized abortion up to 22 weeks of pregnancy.
Australia removed GST on sanitary products, ending the 18-year 'tampon tax'.
Australia launched the Escaping Violence Payment program, offering financial support to women affected by domestic violence.
Women comprised over 50% of the Australian Senate for the first time.
Federal Court ruled that excluding trans women from women-only platforms constitutes indirect discrimination.
